Issues.Title: bug(MatAutoComplete): Material autocomplete behaves differently under karma tests than in production
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

I cannot reproduce it effectively in a stackblitz as it depends on running the karma test runner.

I have produced a reproduction in the following repo: https://github.com/GeeWee/material-autocomplete-repro-case

Basically I take a material-autocomplete example from the stackblitz examples, and it works fine in a real build, but not in tests.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Take a material-autocomplete example from the official examples, such as:
```html
<form class="example-form">
  <mat-form-field class="example-full-width">
    <mat-label>Number</mat-label>
    <input type="text"
           placeholder="Pick one"
           aria-label="Number"
           matInput
           [formControl]="myControl"
           [matAutocomplete]="auto">
    <mat-autocomplete autoActiveFirstOption #auto="matAutocomplete">
      <mat-option *ngFor="let option of filteredOptions | async" [value]="option">
        {{option}}
      </mat-option>
    </mat-autocomplete>
  </mat-form-field>
</form>
```

```typescript
import { Component, OnInit } from '@angular/core';
import {FormControl} from '@angular/forms';
import {map, startWith} from 'rxjs/operators';
import {Observable} from 'rxjs';

@Component({
  selector: 'app-autocomplete',
  templateUrl: './autocomplete.component.html',
  styleUrls: ['./autocomplete.component.scss']
})
export class AutocompleteComponent implements OnInit {
  myControl = new FormControl();
  options: string[] = ['One', 'Two', 'Three'];
  filteredOptions!: Observable<string[]>;

  ngOnInit(): void {
    this.filteredOptions = this.myControl.valueChanges.pipe(
      startWith(''),
      map(value => this._filter(value))
    );
  }

  private _filter(value: string): string[] {
    const filterValue = value.toLowerCase();

    return this.options.filter(option => option.toLowerCase().indexOf(filterValue) === 0);
  }
}
```

Test:
```typescript
describe('AutocompleteComponent', () => {
  let component: AutocompleteComponent;
  let fixture: ComponentFixture<AutocompleteComponent>;

  beforeEach(async () => {
    await TestBed.configureTestingModule({
      declarations: [ AutocompleteComponent ],
      imports: [
        BrowserModule,
        BrowserAnimationsModule,
        ReactiveFormsModule,
        MatAutocompleteModule,
        MatInputModule
      ]
    })
    .compileComponents();
  });

  beforeEach(() => {
    fixture = TestBed.createComponent(AutocompleteComponent);
    component = fixture.componentInstance;
    fixture.detectChanges();
  });

  it('should create', () => {
    expect(component).toBeTruthy();
  });
});
````

2. Run yarn start and assert that the autocomplete comopnent behaviour works exactly like it should in production mode. Assert that you can use the arrow keys and enter to select.
3. Then run yarn test and try to interact with the component in the karma test suite. Selecting the autocomplete component and pressing `arrow_down` will result in the following error:

**chrome**
```
ERROR TypeError: Cannot read property 'nativeElement' of undefined
    at MatAutocompleteTrigger._scrollToOption (:9876/_karma_webpack_/webpack:/node_modules/@angular/material/__ivy_ngcc__/fesm2015/autocomplete.js:910)
    at MatAutocompleteTrigger._handleKeydown (:9876/_karma_webpack_/webpack:/node_modules/@angular/material/__ivy_ngcc__/fesm2015/autocomplete.js:606)
    at MatAutocompleteTrigger_keydown_HostBindingHandler (:9876/_karma_webpack_/webpack:/node_modules/@angular/material/__ivy_ngcc__/fesm2015/autocomplete.js:986)
    at executeListenerWithErrorHandling (:9876/_karma_webpack_/webpack:/node_modules/@angular/core/__ivy_ngcc__/fesm2015/core.js:15265)
    at wrapListenerIn_markDirtyAndPreventDefault (:9876/_karma_webpack_/webpack:/node_modules/@angular/core/__ivy_ngcc__/fesm2015/core.js:15303)
    at HTMLInputElement.<anonymous> (:9876/_karma_webpack_/webpack:/node_modules/@angular/platform-browser/__ivy_ngcc__/fesm2015/platform-browser.js:582)
    at ZoneDelegate.invokeTask (:9876/_karma_webpack_/webpack:/node_modules/zone.js/dist/zone-evergreen.js:406)
    at ProxyZoneSpec.push.QpwO.ProxyZoneSpec.onInvokeTask (:9876/_karma_webpack_/webpack:/node_modules/zone.js/dist/zone-testing.js:332)
    at ZoneDelegate.invokeTask (:9876/_karma_webpack_/webpack:/node_modules/zone.js/dist/zone-evergreen.js:405)
    at Object.onInvokeTask (:9876/_karma_webpack_/webpack:/node_modules/zone.js/dist/zone-evergreen.js:284)
```

**firefox**
```
ERROR TypeError: autocomplete.panel is undefined
    Angular 40
        _scrollToOption
        _handleKeydown
        MatAutocompleteTrigger_keydown_HostBindingHandler
        executeListenerWithErrorHandling
```

#### Actual Behavior

Issues.Title: fix(material/snack-bar): clear timeout upon dismiss with action
Issues.Body:
This is very similar to #4860 where a programmatic dismiss
cancelled the timeout. This patch is for a manual dismiss via
clicking on the snackbar action.

It is especially useful in e2e tests with Protractor, because
Protractor always wait for Angular to become stable. With this patch
Protractor does not need to wait if the action is clicked, saving
potentially a lot of time in repetitive e2e tests.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(material/snack-bar): clear timeout upon dismiss with action" (#22485)

Issues.Title: fix(cdk/testing): incorrectly handling ancestor of compound selector
Issues.Body:
Currently the component harness handles the `ancestor` option by prepending it to the `hostSelector` of the harness. This breaks down if the `hostSelector` is a compound selector, because we end up with something like `.parent .a, .b`, rather than `.parent .a, .parent .b`.

These changes resolve the issue and add a bit of extra logic to account for the case where the selector might include commas inside quotes which will break us, because we split compound selectors on the comma. The logic is loosely based on my changes from https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/38716.

Fixes #22475.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(cdk/testing): incorrectly handling ancestor of compound selector" (#22476)

Issues.Title: cdkTextareaAutosize throws when ng-content has *ngIf
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

[StackBlitz example](https://stackblitz.com/edit/cdktextareaautosize-bug-can-not-read-appendchild)

Steps to reproduce:
1. Create a textarea with the cdkTextareaAutosize directive.
2. Create a wrapper component with a *ngIf for the projected content ```<ng-content *ngIf="true"></ng-content>```. It also happens with *ngTemplateOutlet, so probably it happens with any structural directive.
3. Wrap the textarea with the wrapper component ```<app-wrapper><textarea cdkTextareaAutosize></textarea></app-wrapper>```.
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?
It should project the textarea input into the wrapper ng-content tag and show it when *ngIf evaluates to true.


#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?
It throws: ```ERROR TypeError: Cannot read property 'appendChild' of null...```


#### Environment

- Angular: Last
- CDK/Material: Last
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Mac
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "cdkTextareaAutosize throws when ng-content has *ngIf" (#22469)

Issues.Title: HarnessPredicate doesn't correctly apply ancestor selectors to compound component selectors
Issues.Body:
_Note(@jelbourn): Copied from an internal bug report_

HarnessPredicate.getSelector returns the wrong result in certain cases. E.g., MatButtonHarness and other CDK harnesses are defined as matching one of several possible selectors:

```
  static hostSelector = [
    '[mat-button]',
    '[mat-raised-button]',
    '[mat-flat-button]',
    '[mat-icon-button]',
    '[mat-stroked-button]',
    '[mat-fab]',
    '[mat-mini-fab]',
  ].join(',');
```

I would expect `getHarness(MatButtonHarness.with({ancestor: '.foo'}))` to always find a MatButton that has a '.foo' ancestor. However, the current implementation of https://source.corp.google.com/search?q=HarnessPredicate.getSelector returns:

```
.foo [mat-button],[mat-raised-button],[mat-flat-button],[mat-icon-button],[mat-stroked-button],[mat-fab],[mat-mini-fab]
```

which only applies the ancestor constraint to the first possibility.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "HarnessPredicate doesn't correctly apply ancestor selectors to compound component selectors " (#22475)
